author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Prominent Activist in India Arrested Over Crusade Against Modi in Deadly Riots
description: Teesta Setalvad was detained by an antiterrorism squad to face charges of fabricating evidence against Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
content: A prominent Indian human rights activist who spearheaded a campaign to hold officials responsible for deadly 2002 riots in the western state of Gujarat has been arrested and faces charges of fabricating evidence against the prime minister, Narendra Modi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Jim Tankersley
title: Ukraine War’s Latest Victim? The Fight Against Climate Change.
description: As leaders of the Group of 7 gather in Germany, the scramble to replace Russian fossil fuels is raising concerns that hard-won climate targets will be missed.
content: BERLIN — Russia’s invasion of Ukraine seemed like an unexpected opportunity for environmentalists, who had struggled to focus the world’s attention on the kind of energy independence that renewable resources can offer. With the West trying to wean itself from Russian oil and gas, the argument for solar and wind power seemed stronger than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: MAGA Voters Send a $50 Million G.O.P. Plan Off the Rails in Illinois
description: Republican leaders think a moderate nominee for governor could beat Gov. J.B. Pritzker. But the party’s base seems to prefer a far-right state senator — and he is getting help from Mr. Pritzker.
content: LINCOLN, Ill. — Darren Bailey, the front-runner in the Republican primary for governor of Illinois, was finishing his stump speech last week at a senior center in this Central Illinois town when a voice called out: “Can we pray for you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: 21 Teenagers Found Dead in South African Tavern, Officials Say
description: Initial reports suggested that there had been a stampede inside the club, in the coastal city of East London.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Twenty-one teenagers were found dead early Sunday morning in a tavern in the coastal city of East London, South Africa, the police said, in a tragedy that remains something of a mystery and that has left much of the country, including top officials, reeling emotionally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Austin Ramzy
title: The U.S. and Britain will ban imports of gold from Russia.
description: President Biden announced the decision before the start of a G7 summit meeting in Germany.
content: The United States and other Group of 7 countries will ban imports of gold from Russia, seeking to undercut a key source of revenue for Moscow as it wages war in Ukraine, President Biden said on Sunday as G7 leaders gathered in the Bavarian Alps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Abortion Pills Take the Spotlight as States Impose Abortion Bans
description: Demand for medication abortion is surging, setting the stage for new legal battles.
content: In the hours after the Supreme Court released its decision overturning the legal right to abortion in the United States, nearly 100 requests for appointments flowed into Just the Pill, a nonprofit organization that arranges for patients to obtain abortion pills in several states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Jim Tankersley
title: Rising food and fuel prices loom over the summit.
description: Hovering over the Group of 7 meeting and the NATO summit that follows it is a perilous moment for the global economy, probably the most tenuous since the 2008-09 financial crisis.
content: Hovering over the Group of 7 meeting and the NATO summit that follows it is a perilous moment for the global economy, probably the most tenuous since the 2008-09 financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: In Gee Chun Wins Women’s P.G.A. Championship
description: Despite shooting three over par in the third and fourth rounds, Chun handled a charge from Lexi Thompson to win her third career major tournament.
content: BETHESDA, Md. — In Gee Chun of South Korea rallied after losing the rest of her once-sizeable lead, overcoming a bogey-filled front nine to win the Women’s P.G.A. Championship on Sunday when Lexi Thompson faltered with her putter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Here is what foreign-policy experts are discussing ahead of the G7 meeting.
description: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, this year’s Group of 7 summit was supposed to provide an opportunity to change gears from typical geopolitics and finance, and focus on the future. The top themes were meant to be climate, public health amid the coronavirus pandemic and equity around the globe.
content: Before Russia invaded Ukraine, this year’s Group of 7 summit was supposed to provide an opportunity to change gears from typical geopolitics and finance, and focus on the future. The top themes were meant to be climate, public health amid the coronavirus pandemic and equity around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The First Time I Met My Neighbor, He Was Sitting Outside With a Friend’
description: Learning little things about someone, a tourist’s sleepy retreat and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: How Democrats and Republicans explained the Roe fallout on Sunday talk shows.
description: Democrats used the ruling to criticize Republicans as threats to women and their health care providers, while G.O.P. leaders stressed that states will continue to determine policy on the issue.
content: On the first weekend after the Supreme Court overturned nearly five decades of constitutional abortion rights, Democrats seized on the ruling to portray their Republican opponents as threats to women and their health care providers, while two sitting G.O.P. governors welcomed the decision, as they tried to emphasize that the matter is a local issue with more “debate” to be had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Proud Boys Ignored Orders Given at Pre-Jan. 6 Meeting
description: The directives, given during a video conference, included obeying police lines and keeping away from ordinary protesters. But members of the far-right group played aggressive roles in several breaches at the Capitol.
content: One week before scores of Proud Boys helped lead a pro-Trump mob in a violent assault on the Capitol last year, Enrique Tarrio, the chairman of the group, and some of his top lieutenants held a foul-mouthed video conference with a handpicked crew of members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Bodies They Ritual’ Review: Plush Robes and Cults
description: Angela Hanks’s new comedy is set in Santa Fe, N.M., where five women of color have traveled for some fancy R&R laced with New Age spirituality.
content: The tapas party had not gone over well: “The food was so tiny,” the guest of honor, Faye, recalled. “And I was so hungry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Dobbs, Roe and the Myth of ‘Bodily Autonomy’
description: The end of Roe v. Wade is a reminder that we have human rights and human obligations.
content: “We hold that Roe and Casey must be overruled,” the Supreme Court declared on Friday in its majority opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization. It boggles the mind, really. The fight over abortion that has raged as long as I can remember has taken a decisive turn. The broad spectrum of emotions in reaction to this decision — from outrage to jubilation and everything in between — will be on full display for weeks and months to come. Our feelings about this decision matter. But it is also critical that we continue to examine and clarify the merits of the arguments about abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Reliving Painful History
description: For many people on Capitol Hill, the Jan. 6 hearings are personal.
content: The House Jan. 6 committee’s hearings have revealed unseen footage, unheard testimony and new details about Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election. They’ve also stirred painful memories for those who experienced the attack firsthand. I asked my colleague Emily Cochrane, who’s covered Congress since 2018 and was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, about how the hearings have landed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: The Ruling Was Just the Beginning: Both Sides Mobilize Over Abortion
description: Lawyers, politicians and advocacy groups responded to Friday’s Supreme Court ruling with fresh plans for the fight over abortion rights.
content: The Supreme Court ruling overturning Roe v. Wade has unleashed a frenzy of activity on both sides of the abortion fight, with anti-abortion forces vowing to push for near-total bans in every state in the nation, and abortion rights groups insisting they would harness rage over the decision to take to the streets, fight back in the courts and push the Biden administration to do more to protect abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 26, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 26, 2022.
content: An article on Page 1 about crisis pregnancy centers in New York City includes an outdated reference to Roe v. Wade. After the section went to press, the Supreme Court handed down a decision that overturned Roe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Valerie Hopkins
title: As G7 leaders meet, Russia sends a message with missile attacks.
description: Russia unleashed a new round of missiles at Kyiv on Sunday, the first attack on the Ukrainian capital in weeks, an apparent show of defiance as a summit of the world’s biggest democracies opened on Sunday with new steps to isolate Moscow.
content: Russia unleashed a new round of missiles at Kyiv on Sunday, the first attack on the Ukrainian capital in weeks, an apparent show of defiance as a summit of the world’s biggest democracies opened on Sunday with new steps to isolate Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Ultimate Tennis Disrupter Faces the Wimbledon Crucible
description: Emma Raducanu came out of nowhere to win the U.S. Open at 18 years old. Things have been a little rocky ever since.
content: The British tennis-sphere gasped earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: America the Merciless
description: I can’t help but see our nation’s particular bent toward cruelty.
content: As the Fourth of July looms with its flags and its barbecues and its full-throated patriotism, I find myself mulling over the idea of American exceptionalism. What, if anything, makes this country different from other countries, or from the rest of the developed world, in terms of morals or ideals? In what ways do our distinct values inform how America treats its own citizens?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Under Court’s Shadow, N.Y. Governor Candidates Lob Final Pitches
description: Rulings on abortion and guns shape the final weekend of campaigning before Tuesday’s primary.
content: A pair of seismic rulings by the Supreme Court jolted the race for governor of New York on Sunday, as Democrats and Republicans made final pitches to an electorate that found itself at the center of renewed national debates over guns and abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: For Gun Violence Researchers, Bipartisan Bill Is a ‘Glass Half Full’
description: About two dozen American researchers focus exclusively on how to prevent gun violence. They have waged an often-frustrating battle to translate their findings into public policy.
content: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Jeffrey W. Swanson, a sociologist at Duke University, is no stranger to Washington’s gun laws debate. He has been studying violence and mental illness for more than 30 years, building a scientific case for policies that might reduce gun deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Dahlia Lithwick
description: A conversation with legal journalist Dahlia Lithwick.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Dahlia Lithwick. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: In This Novel of Female Friendship, Birds of a Feather Drift Apart
description: The stylish, reckless heroines of Carlene Bauer’s “Girls They Write Songs About” bond over their similarities, until one decides to settle down.
content: The evolutionary psychologist and anthropologist Robin Dunbar is fond of the term homophily — “love of the same” — to describe why certain people strike up friendships. We’re all aware of the phenomenon in which longtime pals grow alike, but homophily suggests that a fair number of them are actually alike from the start. The relevant proverb: “Birds of a feather flock together.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isvett Verde
title: Growing Up in the Shadow of DACA
description: A generation of young people, still without a pathway to citizenship, tentatively plans for a future that remains uncertain.
content: Think back on the big triumphs of being a teenager: the possibilities presented by a first paycheck; the blend of fear and freedom the first time you drove alone after getting your driver’s license. Upon graduating from high school, scholarship or financial aid made the dream of education possible, opening the door to a far more expansive world along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Schukar
title: A One-Woman Town, Documented for Over 17 Years
description: In 2005, the journalist Alyssa Schukar began photographing the life of Elsie Eiler, the sole resident of Monowi, Neb.
content: The party had already started by the time I arrived in Monowi, Nebraska’s one-woman town, last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Woman Is Charged in Death of Newborn Abandoned in 1985
description: The cold case, from Maine, was among the latest to be closed using genetic genealogy. As a tool for identifying the remains of infants, and determining who their mothers are, the method is not without controversy.
content: At first glance, she looked like a rag doll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: More Than 400,000 Solar-Powered Umbrellas Recalled Over Fire Risk
description: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission recalled the umbrellas, which were sold at Costco, because of the risk of lithium-ion batteries overheating.
content: The authorities have recalled more than 400,000 solar-powered umbrellas sold at Costco because of overheating and fire risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexandra Berzon
title: The Strange Tale of Tina Peters
description: The county clerk has been consumed by election conspiracy theories, lionized by a movement and indicted in a bizarre scheme. Will Republicans nominate her to run elections in Colorado?
content: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. — Just six weeks before the 2020 presidential election — game day for vote-counting bureaucrats — Tina Peters was so proud of her operation at the Mesa County clerk’s office that she invited a film crew in to show it off. There’s no chance of mishap here, she boasted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic Has Prepared His Way. So Has Rafael Nadal.
description: By design, Djokovic usually does not play grass-court events before Wimbledon, and he has won five times with that tactic. Nadal, necessitated by injury, is on the same track this year.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — While the French Open has long been Rafael Nadal time, Wimbledon has become Novak Djokovic time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA’s Return to the Moon Starts With Launching a 55-Pound CubeSat
description: NASA has grandiose plans for sending astronauts back to the moon. Those start with a microwave-size private spacecraft about to lift off.
content: In the coming years, NASA will be busy at the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Schauffele Holds Off Theegala to Win Travelers Championship
description: Xander Schauffele nearly let a three-shot lead slip away, but a birdie on No. 18 gave him a two-stroke victory over Sahith Theegala and J.T. Poston.
content: CROMWELL, Conn. — Before the first round of the Travelers Championship on Thursday, Sahith Theegala, a PGA Tour rookie, was asked if young players in the field were worried about the cluster of veterans spurning the tour to join the rival, Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Missile Strike in Kyiv Rattles Residents After Weeks of Quiet
description: The strike on Sunday morning shook many out of the relative sense of security that has prevailed in Ukraine’s capital since the Russians were pushed out of its periphery in early April.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Olha and her husband, Roman, stood on a concrete platform, carefully avoiding debris and shards of glass, staring at the smoldering building that contained the apartment they moved into one year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Strutting Their Looks
description: The best outfits from LadyLand, the Ailey Spirit Gala and the Songwriters Hall of Fame.
content: LadyLand, the queer music festival started by the nightlife impresario Ladyfag, took place on June 17 at the Brooklyn Mirage. The massive space throbbed with health goths sporting torn mesh, Day-Glo ravers clacking plastic beaded jewelry, shirtless circuit boys clenching their square jaws and the occasional fetishists shaking their exposed buttocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Tick Hunting: The Prey Are Tiny, and the Bait Is Human
description: Climate change and other factors have brought several new species of ticks, and frightening new diseases, to New York in recent years.
content: FAYETTEVILLE, N.Y. — Before he goes out to hunt, Brian Leydet pulls on his hiking boots and his all-white jumpsuit, fetches a homemade flannel flag out of his car and then, most importantly, duct-tapes his socks to his pant legs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: Necromancers, Killers and Presidents, Summoned From the Pages of History
description: Did Abraham Lincoln, like John Wilkes Booth, ever find solace in spiritualism?
content: Is there anything more unknowable than a politician’s soul? Even a figure as exhaustively documented as Abraham Lincoln — whole tomes have been devoted to his marriage, his melancholy, his hats — remains in some essential way a mystery, the private man subsumed by two-plus centuries of folklore and iconography. But he was of course a person who lived and loved and grieved like any other — and like his assassin, John Wilkes Booth, found perhaps some solace in the prospect of an afterworld still reachable from this one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: The End of Roe
description: Plus Russia strikes Kyiv as G7 leaders meet and a Times investigation into China’s surveillance state.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on Friday, ending the constitutional right to an abortion after almost 50 years. The decision, expected after a draft opinion leaked in May, sent a seismic social and political shock through American life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Asmaa al-Omar and Laura Boushnak
title: An Innovator Sold Jordan’s National Dish in a To-Go Cup. Controversy Ensued.
description: Is “mansaf in a cup” a novel way to enjoy the country’s most treasured delicacy, or an affront to its most hallowed traditions?
content: AMMAN, Jordan — The idea struck the restaurateur like a bolt of lightning after he spilled food on his suit while eating in his car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Will LIV Golf Diminish PGA Tour Events Like the Travelers Championship?
description: A prized mainstay of Connecticut’s sporting calendar for 70 years, the Travelers has become more than just a golf tournament.
content: CROMWELL, Conn. — The Travelers Championship in central Connecticut, contested on a golf course beside cornfields, is celebrating its 70th anniversary this week, which makes it one of the oldest continuously operated PGA Tour events. Through the decades, the tournament has changed names and venues, but in a small state lacking a professional franchise in one of the four leading North American sports (the N.H.L.’s Hartford Whalers left 25 years ago), the Travelers has been a prized mainstay of Connecticut’s sporting calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Astros Give Yankees a Tough Series, and a Measuring Stick
description: Aaron Judge carried his team to victory on Sunday, but in a four-game draw, Houston proved the Yankees can’t just coast to the pennant.
content: The best two teams in the American League played a ballgame in the sunshine, bookended by home runs. Jose Altuve drove the first pitch over the left-field wall, and Aaron Judge did the same to the last pitch. More than 44,000 fans packed into Yankee Stadium for the fourth day in a row. Some even stayed for a postgame promotion, playing catch on their field of dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Rudy Giuliani Smacked on Back While Campaigning on Staten Island
description: Mr. Giuliani, who was campaigning for his son, Andrew, a Republican candidate for governor, said a man who hit him in the back said, “You’re going to kill women.”
content: A grocery store worker on Staten Island was arrested on Sunday after smacking Rudolph W. Giuliani on the back while the former mayor campaigned on behalf of his son, a Republican candidate for governor, according to the police and Mr. Giuliani.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Patrick Adams, Master of New York’s Underground Disco Scene, Dies at 72
description: He produced, arranged or engineered many of the era’s biggest nightclub hits, even if his records rarely got much play on the radio.
content: Patrick Adams, a producer, arranger and engineer who brought experimentation, sophistication and infectious grooves to countless soul and disco singles — his fellow producer Nile Rodgers called him “a master at keeping butts on the dance floor” — died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Blitz Bazawule Is Building Bridges Between Worlds
description: The artist and filmmaker, who is directing a new version of “The Color Purple,” publishes his first novel, “The Scent of Burnt Flowers.”
content: DECATUR, Ga. — Blitz Bazawule did not look like someone with the weight of a multimillion-dollar movie on his shoulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: When Nature Calls, Phillies Relievers Have a Place to Go
description: With the Relief Room, a Phillies fan has created an over-the-top shrine to baseball’s most unsung players. It is in his downstairs bathroom.
content: HATBORO, Pa. — It’s the top of the ninth inning at Citizens Bank Park, and the Philadelphia Phillies’ relievers are at it again. They have already blown one lead, with Jeurys Familia and Seranthony Domínguez giving up homers in the seventh. Now after a comeback, the game has unraveled with closer Corey Knebel on the mound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
title: France’s Far Right Surges Into Parliament, and Further Into the Mainstream
description: Marine Le Pen’s National Rally now has a place of power in the political establishment and a chance to prove itself in the eyes of voters.
content: PARIS — In 2017, after the far-right leader Marine Le Pen and her allies won only a handful of seats in parliamentary elections, she blamed France’s two-round voting system for shutting her party out of Parliament despite getting over one million ballots cast in its favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Dobbs Decision Isn’t Just About Abortion. It’s About Power.
description: The legal journalist Dahlia Lithwick breaks down the Dobbs decision and considers the “raw power” of the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority.
content: On Friday, a Supreme Court majority voted to overturn Roe v. Wade. Nearly all abortions are already banned in at least nine states, home to 7.2 million women of reproductive age. And it is likely that other bans and restrictions will follow. As the court’s three liberal justices put it in their dissenting opinion, “One result of today’s decision is certain: the curtailment of women’s rights, and of their status as free and equal citizens.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman, Lucy Tompkins, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Dan Farrell
title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Houston Moved 25,000 People From the Streets Into Homes of Their Own’
description: The nation’s fourth-largest city hasn’t solved homelessness, but its remarkable progress can suggest a way forward.
content: Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic of The New York Times, traveled to Houston to observe an approach to chronic homelessness that has won widespread praise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Scrumptious Bits
description: Drew Schmenner returns with a crossword that may intrigue newer solvers.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Some newer solvers, I’ve been told, feel a bit apprehensive when they face a blank grid. They fear that the puzzle will somehow best them and make them feel “stupid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michele Goodwin
title: No, Justice Alito, Reproductive Justice Is in the Constitution
description: The repeal of Roe v. Wade brings a return of sexual servitude for women.
content: Black women’s sexual subordination and forced pregnancies were foundational to slavery. If cotton was euphemistically king, Black women’s wealth-maximizing forced reproduction was queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenni Avins
title: Vacationing 101 for Those Who Have Forgotten How
description: Vacationing 101 for those who have forgotten how.
content: I used to fancy myself a pretty good vacationer. I’m a lifestyle reporter; excelling at leisure was sort of my thing. But on my family’s recent weeklong trip to Mexico — our first real getaway since the pandemic began, and our first family vacation since our baby was born — I floundered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Lauren McCarthy
title: Pride March in New York Infused With New Sense of Urgency
description: The annual parade included joyous celebration, but the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling and the threat to gay rights cast an undeniable shadow.
content: The festivities began on Sunday with a familiar feel: Revelers adorned in a palette of bright colors, waving rainbow flags and handmade signs, tossed confetti into the air as the roar of screams and bikers revving their motorcycle engines signaled the start of the annual New York City Pride March in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s new task is to ready allies for a long conflict in Ukraine.
description: President Biden will be trying to unite his allies on new ways to isolate Moscow.
content: When President Biden met his Western allies in Europe three months ago, the world was rallying behind Ukraine, and NATO suddenly had a new sense of purpose — its old purpose, containing Russia. There was talk of “crippling sanctions.” President Vladimir V. Putin was in retreat, and talk of victory was in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Schools Are Spending Billions on High-Tech Defense for Mass Shootings
description: The market for weapon detectors and crisis alert badges in schools is booming. But there are questions about whether the new technology is effective.
content: Reid Bauer was finishing lunch period last year at his middle school in the Atlanta area when an alarm began blaring through the halls, warning of an emergency. Reid, then in sixth grade, had never heard the school’s “code red” alert before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: As states ban abortion, demand for birth control and abortion pills is rising.
description: Some women are stockpiling birth control, emergency contraception and abortion pills in case legislation prevents them from accessing it in their home state.
content: Less than 48 hours after the Supreme Court said states could ban abortion, health care providers have noticed an increase in interest in birth control, emergency contraception and abortion pills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Wagner’s Early Operas Shouldn’t Be Mere Curiosities
description: A survey at Oper Leipzig provides an opportunity to reassess the youthful efforts that have been excluded from the composer’s canon.
content: LEIPZIG, Germany — How quickly Richard Wagner changed his mind about “Rienzi,” his first successful opera.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Patients and StatesTurn Focus to Pills
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 26, 2022.
content: “When people say we’re going back to the days before Roe, there’s no such thing as a time machine — we have a very different pharmaceutical landscape.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: The Final Days of Mississippi’s Last Abortion Clinic
description: The Jackson Women’s Health Organization was at the center of the case that overturned Roe v. Wade. Already, supporters are planning new ways to help women in one of the poorest spots in the nation get access to abortions.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — A young woman entered the parking lot of the only abortion clinic in Mississippi, her shoulders hunched. She was accompanied by an older woman and a stone-faced young man with a handgun on his hip. She appeared terrified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California looks to enshrine abortion rights in state constitution.
description: The state constitutional amendment is the latest in a wave of abortion rights legislation that has swept states led by Democrats.
content: SACRAMENTO — California state lawmakers are expected as soon as Monday to put a state constitutional amendment on the ballot that would explicitly protect reproductive rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Muyi Xiao and John Liu
title: ‘An Invisible Cage’: How China Is Policing the Future
description: Vast surveillance data allows the state to target people whose behavior or characteristics are deemed suspicious by an algorithm, even if they’ve done nothing wrong.
content: The more than 1.4 billion people living in China are constantly watched. They are recorded by police cameras that are everywhere, on street corners and subway ceilings, in hotel lobbies and apartment buildings. Their phones are tracked, their purchases are monitored, and their online chats are censored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Happy Marriages, Petty Temptations and Angel Sex
description: Our romance novel columnist, Olivia Waite, has some summer reading recommendations.
content: Romance has been understandably reluctant to put the pandemic on the page. A handful of authors have tried, but audience reaction has been decidedly negative. It seems that acknowledging Covid torpedoes the sense of escapism people are hungry for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Russian Strike on Kyiv Looms Over G7 Summit
description: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.
content: TELFS, Austria — Leaders of the Group of 7 nations said Sunday they would stop buying gold from Moscow and discussed a new American proposal to undercut its oil revenues, even as Russian forces rained missiles on Kyiv for the first time in weeks. The dueling escalation underscored how the war in Ukraine has consumed global politics and the world economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and Reuters
title: N.Y.C. Pride Marchers ‘Nervous’ After Court’s Abortion Ruling
description: Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
content: Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make Eric Kim’s new recipe for a crispy wonton salad, then plan for the days ahead.
content: Good morning. Genevieve Ko here filling in for Sam and channeling his energy: Today’s a good day to think about the food for parties you’re throwing next weekend.
